FROM CLERGYMEN OF VARIOUS DENOMINATIONS.

 From the Rep. Dr.. Gri0fn.-"I esteem Dr. Scott's Family Bible, eminently calculated to promote the cause of truth and pety. It seems scarcely possible for to read daily the Notes and Observations with out becoming a wiser and better man."

 Rsr. Asa Eato', pastor of Christ Church, Boston. -" 1t IS TREASURE WHICH EVERY FAMILY OUGHT TO POSSESS For the success of your undertaking you have my best wishes and fervent prayers"

 Reo. Dr. Joshua Bates, President of Midd2ebary CoHege-"ST, am pleased with your proposals for you success in your undertaking. have no doubt that twill be well patronized by the religious public.'

 Rer. Daniel Sharp, pastor of the Sd Baptit Church, Boston. The more it is read by pious Christians the more extensive will be its circulation"

 Rev. Dr.. Baldcia late pastor of ths 2d Bapt;st Church, BoSton."-" feel free to say that in my est nation It deservedy ranks among our abes and best Commentaries. All the leading doctrines of Chris uanlty as protessed and maintained by many of the most eminent keormers, are in my judgment very hap pily illustrated and enforced"

 Rer. Dr. Dana.-"Dr. Scott's Commentary. has merlted and obtained distinguished popularity The spift which pervades the work is excellent It is the meek, aftechonae, healing yet faithful spirit of the Gospel.

DY order of the Court of Probate for the district of Litch6ed, will be sold public Auction, Tuesday, the 17th of July next lunless previously disposed of at private sale) so much of the real estate of

 ~- ls SAMUEL GUNN, late of Litcheld in said district deceased as will raise she sum of one thousand and fifty dollars. Sale to commence at 10 o'clock A. M. at the late residence of the deceased.

 THOMAS J. GUNN, A9n;,,rs

 RALPH R. GUNN, { """''" 'S' Litchfeld, June 2l, 1897.
.' AUCTION.

THE NETWORK JOURNAL OF COMMERCE, Has been determined on by large number of hb- era gentlemen of that city, and is be edited by the subscriber, with associate of distinguished literary attainments. 1t IS to be DAILY MORNING PAPER ,de- voted principally to commere and manufactures, but

 including politics, literature, and whatever else that may be interesting to intelligent men of business Ad- vertsmens for the theatre, of lottery tckets and of business to be transacted on the Sabbath, will be cluded. It is intended that the Shipping List shall not be surpassed in the country, especially will usual in New-York price current will be inserted soon as arrangements can be made to furnish one, which can be relied upon. The price is the same as other New-York papers, $l0--A Journal will be is- sued SEMI-WEEKLY, containing the principal matter, at $4. To companies subscribing six papers seventh will be included gratis.

 The gentlemen who have determined upon the es- tablishment of this paper have not done it with view to any pecuniary advantage. They have higher motive and one which has long interested the feelings of moral and religious men in Boston, New-York and any amount which may be required. But it is evil dent that to accomplish any valuable purpose wide circulation must be had. "A good subscription list has been obtained in New York, but the enterprise is

 in it's character and has to contend with many and powerful obstacles. To overcome these, no labor nor expense on the part of the projectors the Ed itors will be spared. And they invite the hearty co- operation of all those, who would sustain the business of tic country and it's civil and literary institutions upon the basis of Christian religion and sound nor aliy.

 details of preparation can be arranged. And it is re- quested that names should be returned soon, without the payment of postage, to Arthcr Tappan Esq. New York. DAVID HALE,
THE NETWORK JOURNAL OF COMMERCE

S1C volumes, hOydt OCtGC0, Being the eleuenh American Edition, and complete ds

 aH respects as the best London Edition. THE following are MT. S. T. Armstrong's terms as Il published in the March No. (1827) of the Mis- sionary Herald.

 "In sheep binding, the price is $2l; and in calf binding $50 from which prices very liberal DIs- COUNT is made to agents and others who buy to sell again. The work IS comprised in six volumes royal octavo and well bound and lettered it will be sold as cheap, in proportion to the size of the pages as the publications of the American Tract Society are sold.

 EVERY FOURTH SET GRATTsI That is, any person who takes three sets in sheep binding and pays for them the sum of $72, shall be entitled to one set gratis; if the of $72 is divided equally on all the four sets, it will reduce the amount payable for each of the four sets to S18 instead of M being discount of 25 per cent from the retail price, discount is made tn the same propor- tion on calf binding and on ANY NUMBER OF COPIES, adooe jour, houerer large."

 U The price at the LITCHFIELD BOOK STORE is S2l per single sct and SIS per set where four Or more are taken in conr"sr,,y r,."s,,y

 "The work contains the Old and New Testaments, explanatory of the Scriptures and lastly the Pract- cal Observations. The work is generally known to all who acquainted with the publications of the present day, that it deemed unnecessary to enlarge upon it's contents"

 The first edition of this work, (he constant and n- creasng sale of which proves the high esteem in which it is desevedy held begun in 1783, and published in London, in numbers, consisted of 5000 copies the second in 1895, of2 900; the third in 130 of 000 the fourth in l3l2, 000 and the edition is sere- otye, the largest work submitted to that process. Besides these, eight other editions, consisting alto gether, of 2550 copies, printed in the United States of America, from 1908 to l819."-PhIQdeiphia Recorder.

 The gentlemen who have determined upon the es- tablishment of this paper have not done it with view to any pecuniary advantage. full articles.headline: Tailoring Business. EDWARD SCOTT
full articles.article:
w GUILD inform the inhabitants of Litchfed coun- ty that he has taken the stand formerly occupied by Wm H. Adams where he intends carrying the TAILORING BUSINESSin in all its branches. Peo- pie who feel disposed to favor him with their custom may rest assured that their work will be done in the first style, and in a workmanlike manner.

 Particular attention will be paid to Cutting.

 .t E. SCOTT.

 Litchfeld, June, 1897. l
